abstract: Higher refinancing costs may leave American home builders, including D. R. Horton and Lennar, the two largest, with negative cash flow in 2009.
snippet: Higher refinancing costs may leave American home builders, including D. R. Horton and Lennar, the two largest, with negative cash flow in 2009.
lead_paragraph: Higher refinancing costs may leave American home builders, including D. R. Horton and Lennar, the two largest, with negative cash flow in 2009, according to a report by Goldman Sachs. Goldman changed its neutral rating on homebuilders to cautious. Goldman holds at least $15 million of D. R. Horton’s debt, according to the report.

headline.main: Goldman Sachs Sees More Pain for Home Builders
headline.print_headline: Goldman Sachs Sees More Pain For Home Builders
